Linting Rules

Linting Rules

This is project for managing linting rules that can be used via a linting API as well natively as a collection in a modular way that can be can be evolve using Github. You can find two separate collections in this OpenAPI workspace where you can use these rules to lint an OpenAPI.


Rulesets

These are a list of the rulesets.


Rules

These are a list of the rules.

allowed-integer-format (Link) - To improve interoperability, integer and number formats are constrained to a shared subset. See recommendation RAC_REST_FORMAT_004.

allowed-integer-format:
  x-tags:
    - it
    - RAC_REST_FORMAT_004
  description: |-
    To improve interoperability, integer and number formats are constrained
    to a shared subset.  See recommendation RAC_REST_FORMAT_004.
  message: Type format is “”, expected one of [int32, int64]. 
  formats:
    - oas3
  severity: hint
  recommended: true
  given: |
    $.[?(@.type==”integer”)]
  then:
    field: format
    function: enumeration
    functionOptions:
      values:
        - int32
        - int64
allowed-number-format (Link) - To improve interoperability, integer and number formats are constrained to a shared subset. See recommendation RAC_REST_FORMAT_004.

allowed-number-format:
  x-tags:
    - it
    - RAC_REST_FORMAT_004
  description: |-
    To improve interoperability, integer and number formats are constrained
    to a shared subset. See recommendation RAC_REST_FORMAT_004.
  message: Type format is “”, expected one of [decimal32, decimal64,
    decimal128, float, double]. 
  formats:
    - oas3
  severity: hint
  recommended: true
  given: |
    $.[?(@.type==”number”)]
  then:
    field: format
    function: enumeration
    functionOptions:
      values:
        - decimal32
        - decimal64
        - float
        - double
        - decimal128
api-home-get (Link) - APIs root path MUST have a GET defined, otherwise people won't know how to get it.

api-home-get:
    description: APIs root path MUST have a GET defined, otherwise people won’t know how to get it.
    severity: warn
    given: $.paths[/]
    then:
        field: get
        function: truthy
api-home (Link) - APIs MUST have a root path defined (`/`), to stop forcing all API consumers to visit documentation for basic interactions.

api-home:
    description: APIs MUST have a root path defined (<code class="highlighter-rouge">/</code>), to stop forcing all API consumers to visit documentation for basic interactions.
    severity: warn
    given: $.paths
    then:
        field: /
        function: truthy
array-boundaries (Link) - Array size should be limited to mitigate resource exhaustion attacks. This can be done using `maxItems` and `minItems`, like in the example below. ``` Limited: type: array maxItems: 10 items: type: string format: date ``` You should ensure that the schema referenced in `items` is constrained too. If you delegate input validation to a library or framework, be sure to test it thoroughly and ensure that it verifies `maxItems`.

array-boundaries:
  description: &gt;-
    Array size should be limited to mitigate resource exhaustion attacks. This can be done using <code class="highlighter-rouge">maxItems</code> and <code class="highlighter-rouge">minItems</code>, like in the example below.
    <code class="highlighter-rouge">
    Limited:
      type: array
      maxItems: 10
      items:
        type: string
        format: date
   </code>
    You should ensure that the schema referenced in  <code class="highlighter-rouge">items</code> is constrained too.  If you delegate input validation to a library or framework, be sure to test it thoroughly and ensure that it verifies <code class="highlighter-rouge">maxItems</code>.
  message: Schema of type array must specify maxItems and minItems.<br />
  formats:
    - oas3
  severity: warn
  recommended: true
  given:
    - $.[?(@.type==”array”)]
  then:
    - field: maxItems
      function: defined
    - field: minItems
      function: defined
constrained-additionalProperties (Link) - By default, jsonschema allows additionalProperties. This means that schema validators can be bypassed using further, unspecified fields. While forbidding additionalProperties can create rigidity and hinder the evolution of an API - eg making it hard to accept new parameters or fields - it is possible that this flexibility can be used to bypass the schema validator and force the application to process unwanted information. Disable `additionalProperties` with `false` ``` Person: type: object additionalProperties: false properties: given_name: type: string pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24} ``` Or constraint them using `maxProperties` ``` Person: type: object additionalProperties: type: string pattern: /+39[0-9]{,14}/ maxProperties: 3 properties: given_name: type: string pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24} ``` - no additionalProperties - constrained additionalProperties

constrained-additionalProperties:
  description: |-
    By default, jsonschema allows additionalProperties. This means
    that schema validators can be bypassed using further, unspecified
    fields.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>While forbidding additionalProperties can create rigidity and hinder
the evolution of an API - eg making it hard to accept new parameters
or fields - it is possible that this flexibility can be used
to bypass the schema validator and force the application to process
unwanted information.

Disable `additionalProperties` with `false`

```
Person:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: false
  properties:
    given_name:
      type: string
      pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24}
```
Or constraint them using `maxProperties`
```
Person:
  type: object
  additionalProperties:
    type: string
    pattern: /+39[0-9]{,14}/
  maxProperties: 3
  properties:
    given_name:
      type: string
      pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24}
```
- no additionalProperties
- constrained additionalProperties   message: "Objects should not allow additionalProperties. Disable them with
`additionalProperties: false` or constraint them."   formats:
- oas3   severity: warn   recommended: true   given:
- $.[?(@.type=="object" &amp;&amp; @.additionalProperties
  &amp;&amp;  @.additionalProperties!=true &amp;&amp;  @.additionalProperties!=false )]   then:
- field: maxProperties
  function: defined   
</code></pre></div></div>
has-info-contact (Link) - API MUST reference a contact, either url or email in #/info/contact

has-info-contact:
    x-tags:
        - metadata
    description: “API MUST reference a contact, either url or email in #/info/contact”
    given: $
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    type: style
    formats:
        - oas3
    then:
        field: info.contact
        function: truthy
has-info-description (Link) - API must have description #/info/description

has-info-description:
    x-tags:
        - metadata
    description: “API must have description #/info/description”
    given: $
    severity: error
    type: style
    formats:
        - oas3
    then:
        field: info.description
        function: truthy
has-tag-description (Link) - Tags must have a description.

has-tag-description:
    description: “Tags must have a description.”
    given: $.tags[*]
    severity: error
    then:
        field: description
        function: truthy
has-termsOfService (Link) - API MUST reference the URL of the Terms of Service in `#/info/termsOfService`

has-termsOfService:
    x-tags:
        - metadata
    message: “API MUST reference the URL of the Terms of Service  in
        #/info/termsOfService.”
    description: API MUST reference the URL of the Terms of Service  in
        <code class="highlighter-rouge">#/info/termsOfService</code>
    given: $
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    type: style
    formats:
        - oas3
    then:
        field: info.termsOfService
        function: truthy
has-x-api-id (Link) - The `#/info/x-api-id` field can be used to associate an identifier to an API. This is useful to track an API even when its `#/info/title` changes.

has-x-api-id:
    x-tags:
        - it
        - metadata
    message: “API must have an unique identifier in x-api-id in #/info/x-api-id.”
    description: |-
        The <code class="highlighter-rouge">#/info/x-api-id</code> field can be used to associate an identifier
        to an API.
        This is useful to track an API even when its <code class="highlighter-rouge">#/info/title</code> changes.
    given: $
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    type: style
    then:
        field: info.x-api-id
        function: truthy
has-x-summary (Link) - The `#/info/x-summary` can be used to specify a brief, one-liner description of your API: this is very useful for catalog purposes (eg. this can be shown as your API subtitle in catalogs and developer portals). In OAS3.1 you can use the standard `#/info/summary` field.

has-x-summary:
    x-tags:
        - it
        - metadata
    message: “API MUST have an one-liner #/info/x-summary field containing a brief
        description.”
    description: &gt;-
        The <code class="highlighter-rouge">#/info/x-summary</code> can be used to specify a brief, one-liner
        description of your API: this is very useful for catalog purposes (eg.
        this can be shown as your API subtitle in catalogs and developer portals).

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    In OAS3.1 you can use the standard `#/info/summary` field.
given: $
severity: error
recommended: true
type: style
formats:
    - oas3
then:
    field: info.x-summary
    function: truthy 
</code></pre></div></div>
headers-hyphenated-pascal-case (Link) - All `HTTP` headers MUST use `Hyphenated-Pascal-Case` notation

headers-hyphenated-pascal-case:
    description: All <code class="highlighter-rouge">HTTP</code> headers MUST use <code class="highlighter-rouge">Hyphenated-Pascal-Case</code> notation
    severity: error
    given: “$..parameters[?(@.in == ‘header’)].name”
    message: “‘HTTP’ headers MUST follow ‘Hyphenated-Pascal-Case’ notation”
    type: style
    then: 
        function: pattern
        functionOptions:
        match: “/^([A-Z][a-z0-9]-)*([A-Z][a-z0-9])+/”
hosts-https-only-oas2 (Link) - ALL requests MUST go through `https` protocol only

hosts-https-only-oas2:
    description: “ALL requests MUST go through <code class="highlighter-rouge">https</code> protocol only”
    severity: error
    formats: [oas2]
    type: “style”
    message: “Schemes MUST be https and no other value is allowed.”
    given: $.schemes
    then:
        function: schema
        functionOptions:
        schema:
            type: array
            items:
            type: string
            enum: [“https”]
            maxItems: 1
hosts-https-only-oas3 (Link) - ALL requests MUST go through `https` protocol only

hosts-https-only-oas3:
    description: “ALL requests MUST go through <code class="highlighter-rouge">https</code> protocol only”
    formats: [oas3]
    severity: error
    message: “Servers MUST be https and no other protocol is allowed.”
    given: $.servers..url
    then:
        function: pattern
        functionOptions:
        match: “/^https:/”
integer-format (Link) - Schema of type number or integer must specify a format to express the associated datatype, eg. `int32`, `int64`, You can express similar requirements using the `minimum` and `maximum` properties. See recommendation RAC_REST_FORMAT_004.

integer-format:
    x-tags:
        - it
        - RAC_REST_FORMAT_004
    description: &gt;-
        Schema of type number or integer must specify a format to express the associated datatype, eg. <code class="highlighter-rouge">int32</code>, <code class="highlighter-rouge">int64</code>, You can express similar requirements using the <code class="highlighter-rouge">minimum</code> and <code class="highlighter-rouge">maximum</code> properties. See recommendation RAC_REST_FORMAT_004.
    message: Schema of type number or integer must specify a format. 
    formats:
        - oas3
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    given: |
        $.[?(@.type==”integer”)]
    then:
        field: format
        function: truthy
missing-ratelimit (Link) - Ratelimiting API preserves a service and limits attack scenario [see API4:2019 Lack of Resources & Rate Limiting](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security). APIs should use the following headers at least on successful responses: - `X-RateLimit-Limit`: number of total requests in a give time window - `X-RateLimit-Remaining`: remaining requests in the current window - `X-RateLimit-Reset`: number of seconds before the window resets An example set of headers is the following ``` X-Ratelimit-Limit: 100 X-Ratelimit-Remaining: 40 X-Ratelimit-Reset: 12 ``` A standardization proposal for ratelimit headers is ongoning inside the IETF HTTPAPI Workgroup. See [the draft](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-httpapi-ratelimit-headers/)

missing-ratelimit:
  x-tags:
    - it
  description: &gt;-
    Ratelimiting API preserves a service and limits attack scenario <a href="https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security">see API4:2019 Lack of Resources &amp; Rate Limiting</a>. APIs should use the following headers at least on successful responses:

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code><span class="o">-</span> <span class="err">`</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">RateLimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Limit</span><span class="err">`</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">number</span> <span class="n">of</span> <span class="n">total</span> <span class="n">requests</span> <span class="k">in</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">give</span> <span class="n">time</span> <span class="n">window</span>
<span class="o">-</span> <span class="err">`</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">RateLimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Remaining</span><span class="err">`</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">remaining</span> <span class="n">requests</span> <span class="k">in</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">current</span> <span class="n">window</span>
<span class="o">-</span> <span class="err">`</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">RateLimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Reset</span><span class="err">`</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">number</span> <span class="n">of</span> <span class="n">seconds</span> <span class="n">before</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">window</span> <span class="n">resets</span>

<span class="n">An</span> <span class="n">example</span> <span class="n">set</span> <span class="n">of</span> <span class="n">headers</span> <span class="n">is</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">following</span>

<span class="err">```</span>

<span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Ratelimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Limit</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">100</span>

<span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Ratelimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Remaining</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">40</span>

<span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Ratelimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Reset</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">12</span>

<span class="err">```</span>
<span class="n">A</span> <span class="n">standardization</span> <span class="n">proposal</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">ratelimit</span> <span class="n">headers</span> <span class="n">is</span> <span class="n">ongoning</span> <span class="n">inside</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">IETF</span> <span class="n">HTTPAPI</span> <span class="n">Workgroup</span><span class="p">.</span> <span class="n">See</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">the</span> <span class="nf">draft</span><span class="p">](</span><span class="n">https</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="c1">//datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-httpapi-ratelimit-headers/)   message: Missing ratelimit headers.      formats:
</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">oas3</span>   <span class="n">severity</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">warn</span>   <span class="n">recommended</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nb">true</span>   <span class="n">given</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="p">.[</span><span class="nf">responses</span><span class="p">][?(</span><span class="k">@property</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s">"2"</span> <span class="p">)][</span><span class="nf">headers</span><span class="p">]</span>   <span class="n">then</span><span class="p">:</span>

    <span class="nf">properties</span><span class="p">:</span>

  <span class="n">function</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">xor</span>
<span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">functionOptions</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="n">properties</span><span class="o">:</span>

      <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">RateLimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Remaining</span>
  <span class="n">function</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">xor</span>
<span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">functionOptions</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="n">properties</span><span class="o">:</span>
      <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">RateLimit</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">Reset</span>

  <span class="n">function</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">xor</span>

missing-retry-after (Link) - When a client is either: * throttled out with a 429 status code; * warned about a temporary server issue with a 503 status code; the server should explicitly communicate how long to wait before issuing further requests using the Retry-After header. Retry-After is defined in RFC7231.

missing-retry-after:
    description: |-
        When a client is either:
        * throttled out with a 429 status code;
        * warned about a temporary server issue with a 503 status code;
        the server should explicitly communicate how long to wait
        before issuing further requests using the Retry-After header.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    <span class="n">Retry</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">After</span> <span class="n">is</span> <span class="n">defined</span> <span class="k">in</span> <span class="n">RFC7231</span><span class="p">.</span>
<span class="n">message</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s">"Missing ratelimit header:  in "</span>
<span class="n">formats</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">oas3</span>
<span class="n">severity</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">warn</span>
<span class="n">recommended</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nb">true</span>
<span class="n">given</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="p">.[</span><span class="nf">responses</span><span class="p">][?(</span><span class="k">@property</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s">"429"</span> <span class="o">||</span> <span class="k">@property</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s">"503"</span>  <span class="p">)][</span><span class="nf">headers</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="nl">then:</span>
    <span class="nl">field:</span> <span class="n">Retry</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">After</span>
    <span class="nl">function:</span> <span class="n">truthy</span> 
</code></pre></div></div>
no-additionalProperties (Link) - By default, jsonschema allows additionalProperties. This means that schema validators can be bypassed using further, unspecified fields. While forbidding additionalProperties can create rigidity and hinder the evolution of an API - eg making it hard to accept new parameters or fields - it is possible that this flexibility can be used to bypass the schema validator and force the application to process unwanted information. Disable `additionalProperties` with `false` ``` Person: type: object additionalProperties: false properties: given_name: type: string pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24} ``` Or constraint them using `maxProperties` ``` Person: type: object additionalProperties: type: string pattern: /+39[0-9]{,14}/ maxProperties: 3 properties: given_name: type: string pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24} ``` - no additionalProperties - constrained additionalProperties

no-additionalProperties:
    description: |-
        By default, jsonschema allows additionalProperties. This means
        that schema validators can be bypassed using further, unspecified
        fields.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    While forbidding additionalProperties can create rigidity and hinder
    the evolution of an API - eg making it hard to accept new parameters
    or fields - it is possible that this flexibility can be used
    to bypass the schema validator and force the application to process
    unwanted information.

    Disable `additionalProperties` with `false`

    ```
    Person:
    type: object
    additionalProperties: false
    properties:
        given_name:
        type: string
        pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24}
    ```
    Or constraint them using `maxProperties`
    ```
    Person:
    type: object
    additionalProperties:
        type: string
        pattern: /+39[0-9]{,14}/
    maxProperties: 3
    properties:
        given_name:
        type: string
        pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24}
    ```
    - no additionalProperties
    - constrained additionalProperties
message: "Objects should not allow additionalProperties. Disable them with
    `additionalProperties: false` or constraint them."
formats:
    - oas3
severity: warn
recommended: true
given:
    - $.[?(@.type=="object" &amp;&amp; @.additionalProperties==true)]
then:
    - field: additionalProperties
      function: falsy  
</code></pre></div></div>
no-default-additionalProperties (Link) - By default, jsonschema allows additionalProperties. This means that schema validators can be bypassed using further, unspecified fields. While forbidding additionalProperties can create rigidity and hinder the evolution of an API - eg making it hard to accept new parameters or fields - it is possible that this flexibility can be used to bypass the schema validator and force the application to process unwanted information. Disable `additionalProperties` with `false` ``` Person: type: object additionalProperties: false properties: given_name: type: string pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24} ``` Or constraint them using `maxProperties` ``` Person: type: object additionalProperties: type: string pattern: /+39[0-9]{,14}/ maxProperties: 3 properties: given_name: type: string pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24} ``` - no additionalProperties - constrained additionalProperties

no-default-additionalProperties:
  description: |-
    By default, jsonschema allows additionalProperties. This means
    that schema validators can be bypassed using further, unspecified
    fields.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>While forbidding additionalProperties can create rigidity and hinder
the evolution of an API - eg making it hard to accept new parameters
or fields - it is possible that this flexibility can be used
to bypass the schema validator and force the application to process
unwanted information.

Disable `additionalProperties` with `false`

```
Person:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: false
  properties:
    given_name:
      type: string
      pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24}
```
Or constraint them using `maxProperties`
```
Person:
  type: object
  additionalProperties:
    type: string
    pattern: /+39[0-9]{,14}/
  maxProperties: 3
  properties:
    given_name:
      type: string
      pattern: [a-zA-Z ]{24}
```
- no additionalProperties
- constrained additionalProperties   message: "Objects should not allow additionalProperties. Disable them with
`additionalProperties: false` or constraint them."   formats:
- oas3   severity: warn   recommended: true   given:
- $.[?(@.type=="object" &amp;&amp; ! @.additionalProperties)]   then:
- field: additionalProperties
  function: defined  
</code></pre></div></div>
no-forbidden-headers (Link) - OAS do not allow using the following HTTP headers in a specification file: Authorization, Content-Type and Accept. You MUST use the associate functionalities provided by OAS, instead.

no-forbidden-headers:
  x-tags:
    - standards
  description: |-
    OAS do not allow using the following HTTP headers in a specification
    file: Authorization, Content-Type and Accept.
    You MUST use the associate functionalities provided by OAS, instead.
  message: “ in  “
  severity: error
  given:
    - $..parameters[?(@.in == ‘header’)].name
    - $.[responses][<em>].headers.</em>~
  then:
    function: pattern
    functionOptions:
      notMatch: /^(accept|content-type|authorization)$/i
no-http-basic (Link) - Consider a more secure alternative to HTTP Basic.

no-http-basic:
    description: “Consider a more secure alternative to HTTP Basic.”
    message: “HTTP Basic is a pretty insecure way to pass credentials around, please consider an alternative.”
    severity: error
    given: $.components.securitySchemes[*]
    then:
        field: scheme
        function: pattern
        functionOptions:
        notMatch: basic

patch-media-type (Link) - The PATCH specification explicits that the request body contains a "patch document" describing the changes to be applied to the target resource. To avoid confusion, [this errata](https://www.rfc-editor.org/errata/eid3169) explains that `application/json` is not an appropriate media-type for `PATCH`. A correct example of PATCH using eg. `application/json-patch+json` media-type defined in RFC6902. ``` paths: /books/{book_id}: patch: requestBody: content: application/json-patch+json: schema: type: object example: [{ "op": "add", "path": "/baz", "value": "qux" }] ```

patch-media-type:
  x-tags:
    - standards
  description: &gt;-
    The PATCH specification explicits that the request body contains a “patch document” describing the changes to be applied to the target resource. To avoid confusion, <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/errata/eid3169">this errata</a> explains that <code class="highlighter-rouge">application/json</code> is not an appropriate media-type for <code class="highlighter-rouge">PATCH</code>. A correct example of PATCH using eg. <code class="highlighter-rouge">application/json-patch+json</code> media-type defined in RFC6902.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>```
paths:
  /books/{book_id}:
    patch:
      requestBody:
        content:
          application/json-patch+json:
            schema:
              type: object
            example: [{ "op": "add", "path": "/baz", "value": "qux" }]
```   message: application/json is not an appropriate media-type for PATCH.    formats:
- oas3   severity: error   recommended: true   given: $.[patch][requestBody][content]   then:
field: application/json
function: falsy 
</code></pre></div></div>
paths-http-method (Link) - When you design a REST API, you don't usually need to mention terms like `get`, `delete` and so on in your `paths`, because this information is conveyed by the HTTP method. Instead of using ``` POST /books/1234/delete HTTP/1.1 Host: api.example ``` You can simply call ``` DELETE /books/1234 HTTP/1.1 Host: api.example ``` Similarly you don't need verbs like `list` or `create` because the HTTP Semantics RFC7231 supports this kind of actions natively with proper methods and status code. Instead of ``` POST /create/user HTTP/1.1 Host: api.example Content-Type: application/json {"given_name": "Mario"} ``` You can use ``` POST /create/user HTTP/1.1 Host: api.example Content-Type: application/json {"given_name": "Mario"} ``` returning a proper response ``` HTTP/1.1 201 Created Location: /users/1234 ``` This simplifies securing your API as you know beforehand the kind of action which is going to be performed.

paths-http-method:
  x-tags:
    - it
  description: &gt;-
    When you design a REST API, you don’t usually need to mention terms like <code class="highlighter-rouge">get</code>, <code class="highlighter-rouge">delete</code> and so on in your <code class="highlighter-rouge">paths</code>, because this information is conveyed by the HTTP method. Instead of using
    ```
    POST /books/1234/delete HTTP/1.1

<span class="err">```</span>
<span class="n">You</span> <span class="n">can</span> <span class="n">simply</span> <span class="n">call</span>
<span class="err">```</span>

paths-status (Link) - You must define a `/status` path that can be used to health-check the API. Using this path avoids the arbitrary usage of a server URL for health-check scope. The `/status` endpoint should return a `application/problem+json` response containing a successful status code if the service is working correctly. The service provider is free to define the implementation logic for this path.

response-with-json-object (Link) - JSON responses MUST use JSON objects, in order to be extensible. For example, instead of a list `[1, 2, 3]` you should return an object `{"items": [1, 2, 3]}`. This allows the schema to evolve in a backward compatible ways.

response-with-json-object:
  description: |-
    JSON responses MUST use JSON objects, in order to be extensible. For example, instead of a list <code class="highlighter-rouge">[1, 2, 3]</code> you should return
    an object <code class="highlighter-rouge">{"items": [1, 2, 3]}</code>. This allows the schema to evolve in a backward compatible ways.
  message: JSON responses must use json objects (eg “{}”), not .

  recommended: true

  then:
    field: type
    function: pattern
    functionOptions:
      match: object
security-protection-get (Link) - Your API should be protected by a `security` rule either at global or operation level. Operations should be protected specially when they are tied to non-idempotent HTTP methods like `POST`, `PUT`, `PATCH` and `DELETE`. This is done with one or more non-empty `security` rules. Security rules are defined in the `securityScheme` section. An example of a security rule applied at global level. ``` security: - BasicAuth: [] paths: /books: {} /users: {} securitySchemes: BasicAuth: scheme: http type: basic ``` An example of a security rule applied at operation level, which eventually overrides the global one ``` paths: /books: post: security: - AccessToken: [] securitySchemes: BasicAuth: scheme: http type: basic AccessToken: scheme: http type: bearer bearerFormat: JWT ```

security-protection-get:
    description: &gt;-
        Your API should be protected by a <code class="highlighter-rouge">security</code> rule either at global or operation level. Operations should be protected specially when they are tied to non-idempotent HTTP methods like <code class="highlighter-rouge">POST</code>, <code class="highlighter-rouge">PUT</code>, <code class="highlighter-rouge">PATCH</code> and <code class="highlighter-rouge">DELETE</code>. This is done with one or more non-empty <code class="highlighter-rouge">security</code> rules. Security rules are defined in the <code class="highlighter-rouge">securityScheme</code> section. An example of a security rule applied at global level.
        ```
        security:

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    - BasicAuth: []

    paths:
    /books: {}
    /users: {}
    securitySchemes:
    BasicAuth:
        scheme: http
        type: basic
    ```
    An example of a security rule applied at operation level, which eventually overrides the global one
    ```
    paths:
    /books:
        post:
        security:
        - AccessToken: []
    securitySchemes:
    BasicAuth:
        scheme: http
        type: basic
    AccessToken:
        scheme: http
        type: bearer
        bearerFormat: JWT
    ```
message: "The following operation is not protected by a `security` rule: "
formats:
    - oas3
severity: info
recommended: true
given:
    - $.paths.*.get
then:
    - field: security
      function: schema
      functionOptions:
        schema:
        items:
            type: object
            minProperties: 1
        minItems: 1
        type: array    
</code></pre></div></div>
security-protection-non-idempotent (Link) - Your API should be protected by a `security` rule either at global or operation level. Operations should be protected specially when they are tied to non-idempotent HTTP methods like `POST`, `PUT`, `PATCH` and `DELETE`. This is done with one or more non-empty `security` rules. Security rules are defined in the `securityScheme` section. An example of a security rule applied at global level. ``` security: - BasicAuth: [] paths: /books: {} /users: {} securitySchemes: BasicAuth: scheme: http type: basic ``` An example of a security rule applied at operation level, which eventually overrides the global one ``` paths: /books: post: security: - AccessToken: [] securitySchemes: BasicAuth: scheme: http type: basic AccessToken: scheme: http type: bearer bearerFormat: JWT ```

security-protection-non-idempotent:
    description: &gt;-
        Your API should be protected by a <code class="highlighter-rouge">security</code> rule either at global or operation level. Operations should be protected specially when they are tied to non-idempotent HTTP methods like <code class="highlighter-rouge">POST</code>, <code class="highlighter-rouge">PUT</code>, <code class="highlighter-rouge">PATCH</code> and <code class="highlighter-rouge">DELETE</code>. This is done with one or more non-empty <code class="highlighter-rouge">security</code> rules. Security rules are defined in the <code class="highlighter-rouge">securityScheme</code> section. An example of a security rule applied at global level.
        ```
        security:

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    <span class="k">-</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="nf">BasicAuth</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[]</span>

    <span class="n">paths</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">books</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{}</span>
    <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">users</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{}</span>
    <span class="n">securitySchemes</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="n">BasicAuth</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="n">scheme</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">http</span>
        <span class="n">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">basic</span>
    <span class="err">```</span>
    <span class="n">An</span> <span class="n">example</span> <span class="n">of</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">security</span> <span class="n">rule</span> <span class="n">applied</span> <span class="n">at</span> <span class="n">operation</span> <span class="n">level</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">which</span> <span class="n">eventually</span> <span class="n">overrides</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">global</span> <span class="n">one</span>
    <span class="err">```</span>
    <span class="n">paths</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">books</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="n">post</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="n">security</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">AccessToken</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
    <span class="n">securitySchemes</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="n">BasicAuth</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="n">scheme</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">http</span>
        <span class="n">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">basic</span>
    <span class="n">AccessToken</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="n">scheme</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">http</span>
        <span class="n">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">bearer</span>
        <span class="n">bearerFormat</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">JWT</span>
    <span class="err">```</span>
<span class="n">message</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s">"The following non-idempotent operation is not protected by a</span><span class="err">
</span><span class="s">    `security` rule: "</span>
<span class="n">formats</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">oas3</span>
<span class="n">severity</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">error</span>
<span class="n">recommended</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nb">true</span>
<span class="n">given</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="o">-</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">paths</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">[?(</span><span class="k">@property</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">match</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">/^</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">post</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="n">put</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="n">patch</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="n">delete</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">))]</span>
<span class="nl">then:</span>
    <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">field</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">security</span>
      <span class="nf">function</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">schema</span>
      <span class="nf">functionOptions</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">schema</span><span class="o">:</span>
        <span class="n">items</span><span class="o">:</span>
            <span class="n">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">object</span>
            <span class="n">minProperties</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
        <span class="n">minItems</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
        <span class="n">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">array</span>      
</code></pre></div></div>
securitySchemes-jwt (Link) - Json Web Tokens RFC7519 is a compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties. JWT can be enclosed in encrypted or signed tokens like JWS and JWE. The [JOSE IANA registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/jose/jose.xhtml) provides algorithms information. RFC8725 describes common pitfalls in the JWx specifications and in their implementations, such as: - the ability to ignore algorithms, eg. `{"alg": "none"}`; - using insecure algorithms like `RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5` eg. `{"alg": "RS256"}`. An API using JWT should explicit in the `description` that the implementation conforms to RFC8725. ``` components: securitySchemes: JWTBearer: type: http scheme: bearer bearerFormat: JWT description: |- A bearer token in the format of a JWS and conformato to the specifications included in RFC8725. ```

securitySchemes-jwt:
    description: &gt;-
        Json Web Tokens RFC7519 is a compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties. JWT can be enclosed in encrypted or signed tokens like JWS and JWE. The <a href="https://www.iana.org/assignments/jose/jose.xhtml">JOSE IANA registry</a> provides algorithms information. RFC8725 describes common pitfalls in the JWx specifications and in their implementations, such as:

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    - the ability to ignore algorithms, eg. `{"alg": "none"}`;
    - using insecure algorithms like `RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5` eg. `{"alg": "RS256"}`.

    An API using JWT should explicit in the `description` that the implementation conforms to RFC8725.
    ```
    components:
    securitySchemes:
        JWTBearer:
        type: http
        scheme: bearer
        bearerFormat: JWT
        description: |-
            A bearer token in the format of a JWS and conformato
            to the specifications included in RFC8725.
    ```
message: JWT usage should be detailed in `description` .
given:
    - $.[securitySchemes][?(@.bearerFormat=="jwt" || @.bearerFormat=="JWT")]
then:
    - field: description
      function: truthy
    - field: description
      function: pattern
      functionOptions:
        match: .*RFC8725.*   
</code></pre></div></div>
securitySchemes-oauth-allowed-flows (Link) - The OAuth2 authorization framework defines various [grant types](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-1.3), most notably the [AuthorizationCode](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-1.3.1) and the [Client Credentials](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-1.3.4). Some grant types are now considered insecure and MUST not be used, including `implicit` and `password`. The new [OAuth2.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-1-01) still in draft, removes them and suggests to replace the `implicit` with `authorizationCode` + PKCE defined in RFC7636.

securitySchemes-oauth-allowed-flows:
    description: &gt;-
        The OAuth2 authorization framework defines various <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-1.3">grant types</a>, most notably the <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-1.3.1">AuthorizationCode</a> and the <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-1.3.4">Client Credentials</a>. Some grant types are now considered insecure and MUST not be used, including <code class="highlighter-rouge">implicit</code> and <code class="highlighter-rouge">password</code>. The new <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-1-01">OAuth2.1</a>  still in draft, removes them and suggests to replace the <code class="highlighter-rouge">implicit</code> with <code class="highlighter-rouge">authorizationCode</code> + PKCE defined in RFC7636.
    message: ‘Do not use oauth2 insecure flow: “”.’
    formats:
        - oas3
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    given:
        - $.[?(@.type==”oauth2”)].flows
    then:
        - field: implicit
          function: falsy
        - field: password
          function: falsy
securitySchemes-oauth-http (Link) - OAuth2 endpoints must use `https://`

securitySchemes-oauth-http:
    description: OAuth2 endpoints must use <code class="highlighter-rouge">https://</code>
    message: OAuth endpoints must use https://
    formats:
        - oas3
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    given:
        - $.[securitySchemes][?(@.type==”oauth2”)][*].[?(@property.match(/url$/i))]
    then:
        - field: value
          function: pattern
          functionOptions:
            match: ^https://

servers-description (Link) - Servers must have a description.

servers-use-https (Link) - Servers must use https to ensure the origin of the responses and protect the integrity and the confidentiality of the communication. You can use `http://` only on sandboxes environment. Use `x-sandbox: true` to skip this kind of check.

servers-use-https:
    x-tags:
        - security
    description: |-
        Servers must use https to ensure the origin of the responses and protect the integrity and the  confidentiality of the communication. You can use <code class="highlighter-rouge">http://</code> only on sandboxes environment. Use <code class="highlighter-rouge">x-sandbox: true</code> to skip this kind of check.
    message: “Non-sandbox url   . Add <code class="highlighter-rouge">x-sandbox: true</code> to skip
        this check on a specific server.”
    given:
        - $.servers[?(@[“x-sandbox”] != true)]
        - $.paths..servers[?(@[“x-sandbox”] != true)]
    severity: error
    recommended: true
    then:
        field: url
        function: pattern
        functionOptions:
        match: ^https://.*
string-maxlength (Link) - String length should be limited to avoid an attacker to send very long strings to your service. You can do this in different ways: - specify a `maxLength` - constraint the possible values with an `enum` - use a constrained `format` like `date` or `date-time`. A constrained string using the `date` format. ``` ConstrainedString: type: string format: date ``` Another constrained string using `maxLength`. You can always add further constraints using a `pattern` or a `format`. ``` ZipCode: type: string maxLength: 5 pattern: '[0-9]{5}' ``` For further security, you can always limit string length even in conjunction with `format` and `pattern`.

string-maxlength:
    description: |-
        String length should be limited to avoid an attacker to send very long strings to your service. You can do this in different ways:
        - specify a <code class="highlighter-rouge">maxLength</code>
        - constraint the possible values with an <code class="highlighter-rouge">enum</code>
        - use a constrained <code class="highlighter-rouge">format</code> like <code class="highlighter-rouge">date</code> or <code class="highlighter-rouge">date-time</code>.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    A constrained string using the `date` format.
    ```
    ConstrainedString:
    type: string
    format: date
    ```
    Another constrained string using `maxLength`. You can always add further constraints using a `pattern` or a `format`.
    ```
    ZipCode:
    type: string
    maxLength: 5
    pattern: '[0-9]{5}'
    ```
    For further security, you can always limit string length even
    in conjunction with `format` and `pattern`.
message: Strings (non enum) must specify a maximum length.  
formats:
    - oas3
severity: warn
recommended: true
given:
    - $.[?(@.type=="string" &amp;&amp; !@.enum &amp;&amp; @.format!="date" &amp;&amp; @.format!="date-time" )]
then:
    - field: maxLength
      function: defined 
</code></pre></div></div>
string-pattern-or-format-or-enum (Link) - String length should be limited to avoid an attacker to send very long strings to your service. You can do this in different ways: - specify a `maxLength` - constraint the possible values with an `enum` - use a constrained `format` like `date` or `date-time`. A constrained string using the `date` format. ``` ConstrainedString: type: string format: date ``` Another constrained string using `maxLength`. You can always add further constraints using a `pattern` or a `format`. ``` ZipCode: type: string maxLength: 5 pattern: '[0-9]{5}' ``` For further security, you can always limit string length even in conjunction with `format` and `pattern`.

string-pattern-or-format-or-enum:
    description: |-
        String length should be limited to avoid an attacker to send very long strings to your service. You can do this in different ways:
        - specify a <code class="highlighter-rouge">maxLength</code>
        - constraint the possible values with an <code class="highlighter-rouge">enum</code>
        - use a constrained <code class="highlighter-rouge">format</code> like <code class="highlighter-rouge">date</code> or <code class="highlighter-rouge">date-time</code>.
        A constrained string using the <code class="highlighter-rouge">date</code> format.
        <code class="highlighter-rouge">
        ConstrainedString:
        type: string
        format: date
       </code>
        Another constrained string using <code class="highlighter-rouge">maxLength</code>. You can always add further constraints using a <code class="highlighter-rouge">pattern</code> or a <code class="highlighter-rouge">format</code>.

    ZipCode:
    type: string
    maxLength: 5

    ```

formats:
    - oas3

recommended: true

    !="date-time" )]

    function: schema
    functionOptions:
    schema:
        type: object
        anyOf:
        - required:
            - pattern
        - required:
            - format
        additionalProperties: true

unknown-error-format (Link) - Every error response SHOULD support either RFC 7807 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6648) or the JSON:API Error format.

unknown-error-format:
    description: “Every error response SHOULD support either RFC 7807 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6648) or the JSON:API Error format.”
    formats: [oas3]
    severity: warn
    given: $.paths.[<em>].responses[?(@property.match(/^(4|5)/))].content.</em>~

        functionOptions:
        values:

        - application/problem+json
use-problem-json-for-errors (Link) - Error management is a key enabler of a resilient API ecosystem. Enforcing a consistent schema for errors between different APIs, enables client to properly implement an error management strategy, with positive impacts for users. Error responses should return one of the media-type defined in RFC7807: - `application/problem+json` - `application/problem+xml` An example of a valid response: ``` responses: "503": content: application/problem+json: schema: ... ```

  description: |-

use-problem-schema (Link) - WARN: This rule is under implementation and just provides an hint. Error management is a key enabler of a resilient API ecosystem. Enforcing a consistent schema for errors between different APIs, enables client to properly implement an error management strategy, with positive impacts for users. This rule inspects the schema returned by an error response and verifies whether it contains the main properties defined in RFC7807: `status`, `title` and `detail`. An example of a valid payload is ``` { "title": "Not Found", "status": 404, "detail": "Book does not exist; id: 123" } ``` See recommendation RAC_REST_NAME_007.

use-problem-schema:
    description: |-
        WARN: This rule is under implementation and just provides an hint.

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    <span class="n">Error</span> <span class="n">management</span> <span class="n">is</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">key</span> <span class="n">enabler</span> <span class="n">of</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">resilient</span> <span class="n">API</span> <span class="n">ecosystem</span><span class="p">.</span>
    <span class="n">Enforcing</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">consistent</span> <span class="n">schema</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">errors</span> <span class="n">between</span> <span class="n">different</span> <span class="n">APIs</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="n">enables</span> <span class="n">client</span> <span class="n">to</span> <span class="n">properly</span> <span class="n">implement</span> <span class="n">an</span> <span class="n">error</span> <span class="n">management</span> <span class="n">strategy</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="n">with</span> <span class="n">positive</span> <span class="n">impacts</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">users</span><span class="p">.</span>

    <span class="n">This</span> <span class="n">rule</span> <span class="n">inspects</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">schema</span> <span class="n">returned</span> <span class="n">by</span> <span class="n">an</span> <span class="n">error</span> <span class="n">response</span> <span class="n">and</span>
    <span class="n">verifies</span> <span class="n">whether</span> <span class="n">it</span> <span class="n">contains</span> <span class="n">the</span> <span class="n">main</span> <span class="n">properties</span> <span class="n">defined</span> <span class="k">in</span> <span class="n">RFC7807</span><span class="o">:</span>
    <span class="err">`</span><span class="n">status</span><span class="err">`</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="err">`</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="err">`</span> <span class="n">and</span> <span class="err">`</span><span class="n">detail</span><span class="err">`</span><span class="p">.</span>

    <span class="n">An</span> <span class="n">example</span> <span class="n">of</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">valid</span> <span class="n">payload</span> <span class="n">is</span>
    <span class="err">```</span>
    <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s">"title"</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s">"Not Found"</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s">"status"</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">404</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s">"detail"</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s">"Book does not exist; id: 123"</span>
    <span class="p">}</span>
    <span class="err">```</span>

    <span class="n">See</span> <span class="n">recommendation</span> <span class="n">RAC_REST_NAME_007</span><span class="p">.</span>
<span class="n">message</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="n">Your</span> <span class="n">schema</span> <span class="n">doesn</span><span class="err">'</span><span class="n">t</span> <span class="n">seem</span> <span class="n">to</span> <span class="n">match</span> <span class="n">RFC7807</span><span class="p">.</span> <span class="n">Are</span> <span class="n">you</span> <span class="n">sure</span> <span class="n">it</span> <span class="n">is</span> <span class="n">ok</span><span class="p">?</span> 
<span class="nl">formats:</span>
    <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">oas3</span>
<span class="nl">severity:</span> <span class="n">hint</span>
<span class="nl">recommended:</span> <span class="nb">false</span>
<span class="nl">given:</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">paths</span><span class="p">.[</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="n">responses</span><span class="p">[?(</span><span class="k">@property</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="n">match</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">/^</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="k">default</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">))][[</span><span class="nf">schema</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="nl">then:</span>
    <span class="nl">function:</span> <span class="n">schema</span>
    <span class="nl">functionOptions:</span>
    <span class="nl">schema:</span>
        <span class="nl">type:</span> <span class="n">object</span>
        <span class="nl">properties:</span>
        <span class="nl">status:</span>
            <span class="nl">type:</span> <span class="n">integer</span>
        <span class="nl">title:</span>
            <span class="nl">type:</span> <span class="n">string</span>
        <span class="nl">detail:</span>
            <span class="nl">type:</span> <span class="n">string</span>  
</code></pre></div></div>
use-semver (Link) - The API version field should follow [semantic versioning](https://semver.org/#semantic-versioning-specification-semver).

use-semver:
    description: &gt;-
        The API version field should follow

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><div class="highlight"><pre class="highlight"><code>    [semantic versioning](https://semver.org/#semantic-versioning-specification-semver).
severity: error
recommended: true
message: Specs should follow semantic versioning.  is not a valid version.
given: $.info.version
then:
    function: pattern
    functionOptions:
    match: ^[0-9]+.[0-9]+.[0-9]+(-[a-z0-9+.-]+)?   
</code></pre></div></div>

About this Linting Rules

This project is meant to make linting rules more accessible and usable across the governance of the design of OpenAPIs.
